Name: Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack
Description: In the Triton Safety Instrumented System Attack, TEMP.Veles engaged in network reconnaissance against targets of interest.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may execute active reconnaissance scans to gather information that can be used during targeting. Active scans are those where the adversary probes victim infrastructure via network traffic, as opposed to other forms of reconnaissance that do not involve direct interaction.

Name: Ember Bear
Description: Ember Bear has targeted IP ranges for vulnerability scanning related to government and critical infrastructure organizations.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may scan victim IP blocks to gather information that can be used during targeting. Public IP addresses may be allocated to organizations by block, or a range of sequential addresses.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT has scanned specific lists of target IP addresses.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may scan victim IP blocks to gather information that can be used during targeting. Public IP addresses may be allocated to organizations by block, or a range of sequential addresses.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28 has performed large-scale scans in an attempt to find vulnerable servers.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may scan victims for vulnerabilities that can be used during targeting. Vulnerability scans typically check if the configuration of a target host/application (ex: software and version) potentially aligns with the target of a specific exploit the adversary may seek to use.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29 has conducted widespread scanning of target environments to identify vulnerabilities for exploit.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may scan victims for vulnerabilities that can be used during targeting. Techniques-Description: Adversaries may scan victims for vulnerabilities that can be used during targeting. Name: Winter Vivern

Techniques-Description: Adversaries may scan victims for vulnerabilities that can be used during targeting. Vulnerability scans typically check if the configuration of a target host/application (ex: software and version) potentially aligns with the target of a specific exploit the adversary may seek to use.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41 leverages various tools and frameworks to brute-force directories on web servers.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may iteratively probe infrastructure using brute-forcing and crawling techniques. While this technique employs similar methods to Brute Force, its goal is the identification of content and infrastructure rather than the discovery of valid credentials. Wordlists used in these scans may contain generic, commonly used names and file extensions or terms specific to a particular software. Adversaries may also create custom, target-specific wordlists using data gathered from other Reconnaissance techniques (ex: Gather Victim Org Information, or Search Victim-Owned Websites).

Name: Volatile Cedar
Description: Volatile Cedar has used DirBuster and GoBuster to brute force web directories and DNS subdomains.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may iteratively probe infrastructure using brute-forcing and crawling techniques. While this technique employs similar methods to Brute Force, its goal is the identification of content and infrastructure rather than the discovery of valid credentials. Wordlists used in these scans may contain generic, commonly used names and file extensions or terms specific to a particular software. Adversaries may also create custom, target-specific wordlists using data gathered from other Reconnaissance techniques (ex: Gather Victim Org Information, or Search Victim-Owned Websites).

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon has conducted pre-compromise reconnaissance for victim host information.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's hosts that can be used during targeting. Information about hosts may include a variety of details, including administrative data (ex: name, assigned IP, functionality, etc.) as well as specifics regarding its configuration (ex: operating system, language, etc.).

Name: Andariel
Description: Andariel has inserted a malicious script within compromised websites to collect potential victim information such as browser type, system language, Flash Player version, and other data.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host software that can be used during targeting. Information about installed software may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: antivirus, SIEMs, etc.).

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound has captured the user-agent strings from visitors to their phishing sites.
Techniques-Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host software that can be used during targeting. Information about installed software may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: antivirus, SIEMs, etc.).

Name: Sandworm Team

Techniques-Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host software that can be used during targeting. Information about installed software may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: antivirus, SIEMs, etc.).

Techniques-Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's client configurations that can be used during targeting. Information about client configurations may include a variety of details and settings, including operating system/version, virtualization, architecture (ex: 32 or 64 bit), language, and/or time zone.

Name: APT28

Techniques-Description: Adversaries may send phishing messages to elicit sensitive information that can be used during targeting. Phishing for information is an attempt to trick targets into divulging information, frequently credentials or other actionable information. Phishing for information is different from Phishing in that the objective is gathering data from the victim rather than executing malicious code.

Techniques-Description: Adversaries may search freely available technical databases for information about victims that can be used during targeting. Techniques-Description: Adversaries may search freely available technical databases for information about victims that can be used during targeting. Techniques-Description: Adversaries may search within public scan databases for information about victims that can be used during targeting. Various online services continuously publish the results of Internet scans/surveys, often harvesting information such as active IP addresses, hostnames, open ports, certificates, and even server banners.
